title: 107_hr3068
content: The "Financial Privacy and National Security Enhancement Act" establishes the "Presidential Commission on Financial Privacy and National Security" to fulfill specific duties. The Commission will study financial industry practices for protecting consumer information, ways to improve privacy while maintaining national security. Specific questions include the impact of state privacy laws on federal investigations and the current distribution of information. The Commission will study financial industry practices for protecting consumer information, ways to improve privacy while maintaining national security. Specific questions include the cost of distributing privacy notices, unaddressed financial privacy concerns, and uniform agreement among financial regulators on financial privacy. The potential impact on consumers and the financial services industry of various state laws regarding financial privacy requirements. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 11 members including officials from the SEC, Federal Reserve, Treasury, Justice Department, a State insurance commissioner, and the Speaker of the House or their designees. The Commission consists of 11 members including officials from various government agencies and individuals appointed by the President with expertise in the financial services industry. If a member appointed from Congress or a federal agency leaves their position, they may continue as a member for a limited time. The Commission consists of 11 members appointed for life, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. The Commission consists of 11 members appointed for life, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without pay but receive travel expenses, including per diem in lieu of subsistence. A majority of the members constitute a quorum for hearings. The Chairperson is elected by the members, and the Commission must meet at least once each calendar quarter. Open meetings are required as per Section 552b of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 5. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission may appoint a Director and staff, who can be paid up to $140,000 per year. Additional personnel can be appointed as needed, without following certain civil service laws. Experts and consultants can also be hired according to regulations. The Commission may procure temporary services under regulations. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission has powers to procure temporary services and federal agencies can detail personnel to assist on a reimbursable basis. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, obtain official data from government agencies, and use the United States mails. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and administrative support services can be requested. The Commission, authorized to hold hearings and obtain data, can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services for carrying out its responsibilities under this Act. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress by March 31, 2005, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative or administrative actions. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the final report. During the period from enactment of this Act until the Commission terminates, no State laws can impose requirements or prohibitions on financial institutions regarding the use or disclosure of consumer information. State insurance laws are exempt from this restriction.
